title: 107_hr1098
content: The "Maritime Policy Improvement Act of 2001" may be cited as such. The table of contents for this Act is provided. The "Maritime Policy Improvement Act of 2001" includes provisions for various vessels such as COASTAL VENTURE, American Merchant Marine Memorial Wall of Honor, agricultural cargo residue discharge, maritime liens, R/V DAVIDSON tonnage, Victory Ships exemption, barge documentation, EAGLE documentation, New World Challenge Race vessel waiver, and ASPHALT COMMANDER. The Coast Guard Authorization Act of 1996 is amended to include the vessel COASTAL VENTURE. Additionally, there is an expansion of the American Merchant Marine Memorial Wall of Honor. The Congress acknowledges the historical significance of the United States Merchant Marine in serving the nation during wars since 1775, including its crucial role in gaining independence and supporting allies in World War II. President Franklin D. Roosevelt and military leaders are recognized for their contributions. During World War II, the United States Merchant Marine played a crucial role as the "Fourth Arm of Defense." Over 250,000 men and women served, facing dangers from submarines, mines, and enemy aircraft. Tragically, at least 6,830 members were killed at sea. During World War II, the United States Merchant Marine suffered significant losses: 11,000 wounded, 1,100 died from wounds, 604 taken prisoner, and 1 in 32 died in the line of duty, the highest percentage among US armed services. The Merchant Marine continues to serve. The United States Merchant Marine continues to serve, promoting freedom and meeting high ideals. The Secretary of Transportation may make grants to construct an addition to the American Merchant Marine Memorial Wall of Honor in California. Authorization of appropriations for activities carried out with a grant under this section shall be 50 percent, with $500,000 authorized for fiscal year 2002. SEC. 5. DISCHARGE OF AGRICULTURAL CARGO RESIDUE. The discharge of agricultural cargo residue material from a vessel shall be governed by the Act to Prevent Pollution from Ships. SEC. 6. RECORDING AND DISCHARGING MARITIME LIENS. Section 31343 of title 46, United States Code is amended to allow recording and discharging liens on documented vessels under chapter 121. The Secretary is required to record a notice complying with the regulations. The Secretary must record a notice of claim if accompanied by a declaration affirming the accuracy of the information and sending copies to the vessel owner and other relevant parties. The Secretary must record an unexpired notice of a claim of an undischarged lien or mortgage on the vessel, which must be signed by an authorized official of the person filing the declaration. Upon full repayment of the debt underlying a recorded lien, the claimant must provide the Secretary with a certificate of discharge, which will be recorded. District courts have jurisdiction to determine if a vessel is not subject to a claimed lien or notice of lien, regardless of the amount or parties' citizenship. The venue for legal action regarding vessel liens is determined by where the vessel is located, where the claimant resides, or where the lien notice is recorded. The court may award costs and attorney fees to the prevailing party, unless justified otherwise. A notice of lien expires after 3 years. This section does not change existing laws. The law does not change regarding maritime liens, remedies, or defenses, including the defense of laches. A clerical amendment is made to the table of sections in title 46, United States Code. Amendments are made to notice requirements and approval of surrender of documentation for vessels under title 46, United States Code. The law remains unchanged regarding maritime liens, remedies, and defenses. Amendments are made to notice requirements and approval of surrender of documentation for vessels over 1,000 gross tons under title 46, United States Code. The Marine Act, 1936 (46 App. U.S.C. 1181) and sections 12106(e) and 31322(a)(1)(D) of title 46 will take effect on July 1, 2002. SEC. 7. Tonnage of R/V DAVIDSON: The Secretary of Transportation will determine the tonnage measurement for the vessel R/V DAVIDSON for regulatory purposes. This applies when the vessel complies with specific requirements. SEC. 8. Miscellaneous Certificates of Documentation. The Secretary of Transportation can issue a certificate of documentation for specific vessels for coastwise trade, including LOOKING GLASS, YANKEE, LUCKY DOG, and ENTERPRIZE. The vessels listed include ENTERPRIZE, M/V SANDPIPER, FRITHA, PUFFIN, VICTORY OF BURNHAM, R'ADVENTURE II, ANTJA, SKIMMER, and TOKEENA. The vessels listed in the curr_chunk are TOKEENA, DOUBLE EAGLE2, ENCOUNTER, AJ, BARGE 10, NOT A SHOT, PRIDE OF MANY, AMAZING GRACE, and SHEWHO. SEC. 9 amends Section 3302(l)(1) of title 46, US Code to exempt the SS Red Oak Victory and SS American Victory. SEC. 10 deals with the certificate of documentation for 3 barges. The Secretary of Transportation may issue a certificate of documentation for employment in the coastwise trade for specific vessels, including the former Navy deck barge JIM and the former railroad car barge HUGH. The former railroad car barge TOMMY is 185 feet long and 34 feet wide. It can only be used as a floating platform for launching fireworks. SEC. 11. CERTIFICATE OF DOCUMENTATION FOR THE EAGLE. The Secretary of Transportation will issue a certificate of documentation for the vessel EAGLE for coastwise trade if owned or chartered by a State entity. The vessel EAGLE can receive a certificate of documentation for coastwise trade if owned or chartered by a State entity, and must be operated in conjunction with scour jet operations or dredging services adjacent to state-owned facilities. SEC. 12. WAIVER FOR VESSELS IN NEW WORLD CHALLENGE RACE. Beginning April 1, 2002, 10 sailboats in the race can transport guests without payment until 60 days after the race ends or December 31, 2003. SEC. 13. VESSEL ASPHALT COMMANDER may be transferred to a foreign registry or sold to a non-US citizen.
